deck: A one shot character who was a Kryptonian scientist who was banished to the Phantom Zone in the Pre-Crisis universe.
description: Created a cabinet that changed people, but could not change them back. Banished to the Phantom Zone for 50 decatrons. A warning was engraved on the cabinet and it was ejected into space, where it landed on Earth.
name: Zan-Zoll

deck: Leader of The Power Cult
description: He believed that a nuclear Armageddon was coming and was preparing his cult for it.

deck: Scientist who experimented on himself and gave himself the ability to make objects and himself levitate.
description: The levitational energy from his experiment was driving him insane making him steal and try to kill Giant Man (Bill Foster).
name: Air Walker

deck: Pyromaniac and ex member of the Power Cult.
description: Daughter of Reverend Stryker who kileed her boyfriend because he would not leave the Power Cult.She was willingly offering her soul to take Zarathos place as Mephisto's thrall but was stopped by her father.
name: Veronica Stryker

deck: Bharti is one of Nagraj's closest friends. She is also the owner of Mahanagar's media giant Bharti Communications.
name: Bharti

deck: A character from Poot.
description:
Origin

Count Flatyuloff is a character from the Fantagraphics comic, Poot.

Creation

Count Flatyuloff was created by Walt Holcombe.

Character Evolution

The Count used to be a lover of Count Stinkenpuss, but the two go through a bitter break up, and Flatyuloff leaves him for someone else after an argument. The pair then become nemeses.

After Count Stinkenpuss wins a cat contest with his cat, Mr Lovely, Flatyuloff becomes jealous and flies into a rage. He kidnaps Mr Lovely and flees in a plane, taking the cat to Mount Kilimanjaro. His intention is to throw the cat from the plan and into a volcano, to make Stinkenpuss cry. But when he ejects Mr Lovely from the plane, Stinkenpuss catches him. Flatyuloff then dies when his plane is shot down, and he crashes into Kilimanjaro.

Major Story Arcs

Count Flatyuloff does not appear in any major story arcs.

Powers and Abilities

Count Flatyuloff does not have any special powers or abilities.

issue_credits.name: Things Just Get Away From You

name: Count Flatyuloff

volume_credits.name: Things Just Get Away From You

deck: Skrull!
name: Skragg

deck: Hero who substituted for his half-brother Thomas Halloway on numerous occasions as The Angel.
description:
Brief History

Half-brother to the original Angel. In modern times, he was living as a homeless man in and beneath Manhattan, where he was ambushed and murdered by Zeitgeist. Due to continuity differences he has been retconned as one of two men who had assumed the identity of the Angel
name: Angel (Simon Halloway)

deck: Supercollider is an ever-evolving creature who seems to be shedding her alter ego in favor of a strange being who conforms only to the rules of order.
description:
Origin

Joanie Cosmic was a notable radio personality and celebrity, who would be involved in the christening of a new ultra high tech supercollider in Utah as a part of a radio promotion. The massive underground supercollider designed to study and aid research in quantum physics. Unfortunately upon activation a fatal error would occur, with the supercollider creating and being swallowed in its entirety into a miniature black whole. Joanie undergoes radical transformation, a profound change on the quantum level, empowering her with the superhuman ability to manipulate reality on any scale by the application of rules of subatomic particles. Naming herself Supercollider, she is now a superhero and also appears to be in constant evolution, her personality conforming to the rules of order as she sheds some of her more human qualities. Her villains and nemesis include Professor Hieronymus Higgens, Senator Vile and Elemental Man. She is allies with Meridian and Omni-Engine.

Creation

Supercollider is a Boom! Studios published character that first appears in the 2012 series Deathmatch, appearing in its debut issue Deathmatch #1. Supercollider is designed and created by writer Paul Jenkins and artists Carlos Magno and Michael Garland, writers and artists of the series.

Character Evolution

Supercollider plays a small supporting role in Deathmatch, she is one of the few victims of the death match and rarely appears otherwise.

Major Story Arcs

Deathmatch

Supercollider is transported by mysterious unseen forces to an enclosed complex along with a various assortment of other heroes, villains and vigilantes. Neither her or the other heroes or villains understand why they are there or who orchestrated the situation, and they seem powerless and kept in check by powerful guards made of light.

Powers and Abilities

Supercollider possesses the ability to apply the laws of subatomic physics and quantum physics in regular conventional human interaction.
name: Supercollider

deck: Friend of Rick Jones
description:
She is a singer and her agent is Mordecai Boggs, the same as Rick Jones'.

Together, they are to form a duo "Rick&Dandy". Mordecai set up a tour in fourteen cities starting with Denver. Rachel, pretty much like Rick, is reluctant to have a partner.

During their trip to Denver, they come face to face with Nitro and she runs away.
name: Rachel Dandridge

deck: Toy Boy is a former industrial spy and thief turned superhero trying to make up for his past crimes. And he likes to blow stuff up... lots of stuff.
name: Toy Boy

deck: A somewhat crazed taxi driver whom encountered Shang-Chi and the Defenders on some occasions, and is based on Groucho Marx.
description:
Major Story Arcs

Rufus T. Hackstabber is a memorable and goofy character who appears as a crazed taxi-driver when he drives Shang-Chi, the Master of Kung-Fu, to different locations. He keeps referring to Shang-Chi as "Chang-Shee".

Sometime later he encounters the Defenders, when he becomes involved in a murder case with the Defenders and two detectives from his hometown, Typhoon and Cutlass. It was during this time Rufus admitts to having a crush on the woman detective named Typhoon. He asks her out, even though he knows she is married. She harshly rejects his offer.

Some months later, Rufus again comes into contact with some of the Defenders when he drives Hellstrom and Hellcat towards a mystery mansion. Later on, he also comes into contact with the Defenders Beast and Iceman. All of them dislike Rufus for his extreme way of cab-driving and strange comments. Rufus however helps out his newfound 'friends' til the murder-case is solved. At the end of the issue he seems to somehow come into possession of the Lesser Grey God, a sculpture of great mystical power, which he uses as a hood ornament.

Trivia

The character strongly resembles comedian Groucho Marx. Hackstabber's name is a play on Rufus T. Firefly, a character that Groucho played during his carreer.
name: Rufus T. Hackstabber

deck: Father of Jonathan Crane, better known as the Scarecrow.  Tested his experiments on his son until his sudden death.
description:
Origin

Dr. Crane works at a government lab making a chemical called Bowlby, but died before completion. He would often use his son, Jonathan as a test subject, locking him in the cellar for hours on end, terrifying the boy to tears. Dr. Crane died while day while Jonathan was locked in the cellar and it took days before the police came looking for him.

Creation

Dr. Crane was created by Gregg Hurwitz and David Finch for their story arc Circle of Violence in Batman: The Dark Knight.

Major Story Arc

Circle of Violence

While Scarecrow puts Batman under the effects of his Fear Toxins, he reflex on his childhood. He remembers his father Dr. Crane locking him up in the basement. He remembered his father telling him that putting him in the cellar for hours to scare him was for science. Dr. Crane would often push Jonathan into the hole against his will. Jonathan remembers the time his father came into his room late at night to tell him his mother was dead and that it was the two of them from now on. Finally Jonathan remembers the day his father locked him up and then died, leaving him trapped in the cellar for days.

Other Media

Television

Gotham

Dr. Crane makes an appearance in the episode titled "The Fearsome Dr. Crane" Dr. Crane is killing people who are in a phobia support group. His name is Gerald, but he is called Jon- most likely using his son's name as an alias. A young Jonathan Crane makes a brief appearance.

issue_credits.name: Death of the family, Toc Toc; Mofarse; El pasado no muerto
El fantasma en la máquina; Espejito, espejito
El guardián de mi hermano; La caída de la casa Wayne, conclusión; Ciclo de violencia

name: Dr. Crane

Resurrected Warrior
Cassandra the Dust Eater

塵食いのカサンドラ
deck: A former No. 1 and one of the eight strongest warriors ever created by the Organization. Cassandra was a shy and quiet individual, who did not socialize with others. She was named Cassandra the 'Dust Eater' due to her unorthodox fighting style. She was one of the three warriors resurrected by the Organization and the strongest among them.
name: Cassandra

deck: A Mandalorian leader of the Death Watch faction during the clone wars. Vizsla allied with Count Dooku to try and overthrow the Duchess of Mandalore in order to rule the planet.
description:
Origin

Pre Vizsla, a member of the Vizsla clan, followed in the footsteps of one of his relatives, Tor Vizsla, and became the leader of the Mandalorian Death Watch. During his time as leader, he committed terrorists acts against his own people to inspire fear and show that the warrior class of Super-Commandos should again be the ruling party. Though the current Mandalorian Duchess Satine sought the aid of her long-time friend/love interest, Obi-Wan Kenobi, who after many battles with Pre and the Death Watch, eventually captured him.

Later as the Clone Wars raged on, Mandalore, a neutral planet, fell prey to a group of pirates and gangsters under the leadership of Darth Maul and Savage Opress, Pre Vizsla was freed by the brothers and offered leadership of his people in exchange for his loyalty.

Death

Pre Vizsla was not exactly loyal to Darth Maul, and planned to kill the Nightbrothers, but Maul had anticipated this, and looked to Mandalorian culture for a precedent to challenge Pre Vizsla without the interference of his troops, Maul found just that, and challenged Pre to an honorable battle to the death. Maul came out victorious, sending Pre to fall to his death at the close of their battle.
name: Pre Vizsla

volume_credits.name: Star Wars: The Clone Wars - Defenders of the Lost Temple

Creation

name: Yun Guang Han

deck: A teddy bear superhero.
description:
Origin

SuperTed is a Welsh teddy bear with superpowers.

Creation

SuperTed was created by Mike Young. Young originally created the character for his son, to soothe the boy at night because he was afraid of the dark. He went on to write over a hundred books about the bear.

Character Development

SuperTed is thrown out with the rubbish when he is found to be defective, at the toy factory where he was made. But a Spotty Man finds him, and brings him to life with cosmic dust. He activates his powers by uttering a secret magic word, after being granted the power to fight evil by Mother Nature.

SuperTed's costume is located underneath his fur, which he unzips and leaps out of when transforming.

Major Story Arcs

SuperTed does not appear in any major story arcs.

In Other Media

SuperTed was also the star of a British animated show, which was originally made for the Welsh television channel S4C. The show was later dubbed into English, and went on to win several awards. A second series, The Further Adventures Of SuperTed was later produced by Hanna-Barbera, but this version of SuperTed was entirely different, with a complete change in cast and production staff.

Powers and Abilities

When SuperTed says the secret magic word, he is transformed into a superhero bear, who can fly. He also has super strength, and is capable of super speed.
name: SuperTed

deck: The steward of assassins of Pitll Pawab (The Isle of Assassins).
description: He joined forces with Visis to battle against the armies of K'ai.

first_appeared_in_issue.name: Holocaust At the Heart of the Atom

issue_credits.name: Holocaust At the Heart of the Atom

name: Krylar

deck: A character from SuperTed.
description:
Origin

Spotty is SuperTed's friend.

Creation

Spotty was created by Mike Young. Young originally created the SuperTed characters for his son, to soothe the boy at night because he was afraid of the dark.

Character Development

Spotty is an alien from the planet Spot, who finds SuperTed abandoned at the toy factory where he was made. He brings the bear back to life with cosmic dust, and takes him to see Mother Nature, who gives SuperTed special powers.

Major Story Arcs

Spotty does not appear in any major story arcs.

In Other Media

Spotty was also a character in the British animated show, which was originally made for the Welsh television channel S4C. The show was later dubbed into English, and went on to win several awards. A second series, The Further Adventures Of SuperTed was later produced by Hanna-Barbera, but this version of SuperTed was entirely different, with a complete change in cast and production staff. Spotty was the only original supporting character to remain in the second series.

Powers and Abilities

Like SuperTed, Spotty can fly.
name: Spotty

deck: Jerry Feldon came upon his H-Dial while working as a soda jerk at an ice cream parlor. An old woman, an H-Dialer from the 40s, it would seem, had left it on her plate. Jerry's first attempt at super heroics was less than a success.
description:
Origin

He save a person from getting run over and a drunk driver from a burning car, but ended up breaking every bone in his body. The first attempt scared Jerry off the H-Dial for a while, for fear he'd return to a state where he was injured. Instead, he discovered he got a new hero each time. He just enjoyed being in the super powered body and started skipping work. One night, he burned down Heaton's abandoned car factory.

After a couple days of this, he decided to turn to crime fighting. After a few days of patrolling and finding nothing, he finds a drug dealer. When the dealer laughed in his face, he punched him, breaking his ribs. Jerry rushed him to the hospital and quickly escaped. He was depressed for a while, but cheered up when his crush, Molly, agreed to a date with him. That day, the ice cream parlor he worked at was robbed. Jerry transformed to save the day. The robber was caught, but Molly got shot and the parlor burned down. Jerry ran from the parlor to a phone booth, called a suicide hotline, and explained all of this. After the call, he flew into outer space and turned back to normal, intending to kill himself.

His attempt failed when Superman himself saved Jerry. At the hospital, he saw Molly, still in critical condition. He went to the roof and found the woman who originally had the H-Dial. She intended to kill herself, but Jerry was able to talk her out of it. With the H-Dial lost, Jerry started to live a normal life. He joined the suicide hotline, became friends with Doug (the guy he spoke with), and dated Molly.

Heroes Jerry Turned Into

  • Afterburner
  • The Bouncer
  • The Blur
  • The Wake
  • Winged Victory
  • The Wrecker
  • Powerhouse
  • Napalm
name: Jerry Feldon

deck: Heavy Load is a chemist who used to work for good, but centuries of experiments have taken their toll, and his cognitive systems were degraded through chemical exposure. He now follows Megatron as a Decepticon.
name: Heavy Load

deck: An Aerialbot from IDW's Transformers Continuity. His alt-mode is an F14 Tomcat
description:
Origin

An Aerialbot from IDW's Transformers Continuity. His alt-mode is an F14 Tomcat. Barrel Roll may be hotheaded but believes in the concept of an innate Autobot Moral. Barrel Roll has a strong distrust for all Decepticons. Barrel Roll joined the Autobot cause to give them a countermeasure to the Decepticon Seekers.

Creation

Barrel Roll was created by IDW for Transformers: Robots in Disguise issue #3 by writer John Barber and editor Carlos Guzman. He was also seen in the Prequel Digital Comic Transformers: Autocracy.

Major Story Arcs

IDW Continuity

Autocracy

Barrel Roll joined the other Aerialbots in the fight against Megatron after Orion Pax took the Matrix of Leadership and became Optimus Prime. He provided support against the Decepticons and fought against the Seekers in the battle that followed.

Chaos

After the rebirth of Cybertron and the reunification of the Transformer race and Barrel Roll accepted they would have to rebuild together.

Robots in Disguise

With the other Aerialbots, Barrel Roll was sent in to help manage an angry Decepticon crowd after the death of Senator Ratbat. When Dirge angrily stormed off after refusing to believe Starscream and the Autobots' spin on the situation, Barrel Roll ran after him, suggesting to him that, as fliers, they should stick together. Before the offer could be commented on, a massive and mysterious explosion engulfed Barrel Roll. Dirge was spared.

Powers & Weaknesses

Like the other Aerialbots Barrel Roll can fly at speeds of up to Mach 5 and has a range of 1500 miles. In his alt-mode he can shoot air-to-air heat-seeking missiles and, in robot-mode, carries a plasma rifle. Unlike the other Aerialbots he can't combine to form Superion. Barrel Roll sometimes allows his hatred of the Decepticons to cloud his judgement.

Characteristics

  • Allegiance: Autobot
  • Sub Group: Aerialbot
  • Function: Warrior/Scout
  • Alt-Modes: Cybertronian Jet, F-14 Tomcat
  • Color Schemes: Green/Yellow (G1, IDW)
name: Barrel Roll

deck: One of three criminals that escape from the Kree homeworld, Hala.
description: Dekker and a space ship full of criminals escape from the Kree homeworld, Hala. The ship lands on top of a building and Spidey swings over to greet the Kree criminals as they disembark. Dylon-Cir and Dekker tell Spidey that they are looking for the Avengers to help them defend their planet from attack. What Dylon-Cir doesn't say is that what he really wants is to trick the Avengers into doing their bidding.
name: Dekker

aliases:
Doctor Fate
Dr. Fate
Khalid Ben-Hassin
deck: The new Doctor Fate of the re-imagined Earth 2.
description:
Origin

Little is known about how Khalid was chosen by Nabu to become Doctor Fate, all that is known is that friend and ally, Hawkgirl gained her powers/wings at the same time with him. Since then, Khalid has been very wary of the Helmet of Fate, often refusing to wear it due to the toll it takes on his sanity.

Creation

The new Earth 2 Doctor Fate was created by Earth 2 writer James Robinson and designed by Brett Booth.

Major Story Arcs

The Tower of Fate

Khalid along with Jay Garrick and his mother are transported to Nabu's Realm by Wotan, a mage who resents Nabu and wishes to take his powers. Wotan has tasked Khalid and Jay with obtaining Nabu's Helm from within the Tower of Fate, and bring it to him, using Jay's mother as leverage.

The two enter the tower and begin the ascent to the top, however are confronted by a great beast that acts as a guardian to the tower. Jay manages to run himself and Khalid to safety before deciding to turn back and fight the beast head on, leaving Khalid to climb the rest of the tower alone. Jay's courage inspires Khalid, and as he reaches Nabu's Helm he accepts the responsibility even knowing it will probably drive him insane. Willingly he puts on the helmet and becomes Doctor Fate, rushing to Jay's aid by defeating the beast guardian.

Doctor Fate and Flash exit the tower, and Fate begins to fight Wotan, stating that Nabu's powers will never be his. With Wotan hurting Doctor Fate, Nabu tells him that Wotan has been in his realm for too long, absorbing it's power. Fate then opens a portal to Earth, transporting everyone from Nabu's Realm through it. Using his new found powers by listening to Nabu, Khalid manages to defeat Wotan, teleporting him to another dimension. With The Green Lantern appearing at the scene, Alan suggests leaving quickly due to the incoming World Army. Doctor Fate manages to teleport the three heroes to hide out at Alan's home, where Fate informs them to turn on the TV and learns of the impending war with Dherain.

The initial invasion of Dherain by the Wonders of America went rather well as they easily decimated Steppenwolf's forces. However, Steppenwolf sent his Hunger Dogs to confront both the Wonders and the World Army. Steppenwolf's Hunger Dogs easily defeated both teams with The Beguiler deflecting his magical energy back at him which knocked him out. Although they were defeated, the Hunger Dogs didn't kill them. When the Wonders and World Army eventually woke up, Khalid healed them of their injuries and teleported them to the battlefield where Steppenwolf and his forces had decimated the World Army who had ordered a retreat. Khalid opened another portal to allow Jay Garrick to transport injured soldiers to medical aid, before they could all return, Alan Scott went to attack Steppenwolf, while he initially had the upper hand he was attacked from behind by Brutaal and proceeded to be beaten up by the combined might of Steppenwolf and Brutaal, meanwhile the Wonders of America could only looks on as their leader was defeated.

deck: A blind martial artist and a disciple of the Great Sage Fist.
description:
Powers and Abilities

Lugh as stated by his master Ogata is either the strongest or second strongest disciple in YOMI. Lugh has been shown to defeat other high class disciples such as Siegfried and Thor with ease. Lugh has had training from Ogata Isshinsai in his personal style of Ancient Martial Arts and his specialization is locks, which gave him the nickname submission man. Lugh is blind and is strong because of his handicap. He can sense the Ki being released from muscles and has learned to predict where attacks will come from based on his opponents muscle movement. Lugh's hearing is superhuman and he has admitted he can hear sound from one kilometer away.

Beyond his fighting Lugh is an intelligent and perceptive combatant who can get inside his opponents head. Lugh can psychological manipulate his foes often making them lose their cool in a fight. Siegfried and Niijima have both commented on this. Lugh is able to dicern his opponents fighting style and how best to counter it. Lugh can even copy or intergrate his opponents moves into his own ahown after he copied Takeda's Warp Punch as his Utsusemi Kyokushi technique.

Lugh's greatest talent and what makes him so strong in YOMI is his level of Ki. Lugh has the highest level of Ki and even though he cannot control it yet, if he did he would be the closest to master level according to Ogata. Lugh ki is strong enough that when Miu Furinji felt it she instantly assumed a defensive stance, Takeda lost his cool and began to fight wildy, even Shigure (a grnad master class fighter) went to the Shinpaku Alliance's aid since she thought Lugh was a danger to all the disciples present.

Techniques

  • Inner Eye - Lugh paces the opponent's and memorizes their attack pattern in order for him to react before the opponent can. Since Lugh can't see he senses their Ki and listens to their muscle patterns in order to get the pace down.
  • Kyokuten Ude Karami Otoshi - Lugh grabs his opponents arm and neck at the same time while upside down and brings their arm back and upwards trying to dislocate it.
  • Ogat-Ryuu Floating Throw - Lugh first grabs his opponent by their sleeves using his fingers, then throws them using only the centrifugal force of his movements.
  • Ogata-Ryuu Gliding Step - Lugh moves his at such a fast rate he looks like he's making clones of himself.
  • Ogata-Ryuu Submission Penetrating Hit - Lugh attacks the opponent's joints with multiple strikes in order to dislocate and force all the joints out of their socket.
  • Ogata Zatjuuori - Lugh grabs one of his opponent's legs and then proceeds to slam His knees into the knee socket of his opponent's legs.
  • Seikuken - A combat method that involves controlling the entire radius within one's arm length, creating a spherical shield around oneself. It can be used for offense and defense. Lugh Seikuken seems to spiral around himself.
  • Utsusemi Kyokushi - Lugh's version of Takeda's Warp Punch technique. Lugh lets himself be hit by his enemy's attack, using his ki to confuse his opponent into thinking that they landed a finishing blow, while actually targeting the opponent's joints the moment he gets hit. Just like the Warp Punch technique.
name: Lugh

deck: A deadly archer and enemy of Green Arrow. Protege of Robert Queen.
description:
Creation

Komodo first appeared in Green Arrow #17, and was created by Green Arrow writer Jeff Lemire and artist Andrea Sorrentino.

Origin

Simon Lacroix, the man who became Komodo, was born into a poor family, but became a high-ranking member of Queen Industries; he was even taught archery by Robert Queen, father of Oliver Queen. Lacroix was part of Queen's expedition to find the legendary "Green Arrow" - a mystical arrow belonging to the head of the Arrow Clan, said to bring its owner true enlightenment and even immortality. However, the Outsiders - the union of the seven "weapon clans" which secretly maintained order around the world- appealed to Lacroix's greed and convinced him to kill Robert, leaving himself the only contender to become the new head of the Arrow Clan. He also kidnapped Emiko, the daughter of Robert and the Japanese archer Shado, and handed Shado to Count Vertigo of Vlatava, where she was imprisoned. Lacroix adopted the identity of the masked archer Komodo, and continued to work with the Outsiders through their front corporation, Stellmoor International.

Major Story Arcs

The Kill Machine

After Stellmoor bought out Queen Industries, Lacroix's first act as Komodo was to murder the CEO of Queen Industries and destroy Q-Core, framing Oliver Queen for the former crime. Aware of Queen's secret identity as Green Arrow, Komodo tricked Ollie into believing his assistants Jax and Naomi Singh were killed by an explosion in the Q-Core building; Komodo had actually taken them hostage, but killed Jax when he refused to talk.

Komodo then clashed with Green Arrow a second time, with assistance from Emiko. Combined, they hit Oliver seven times, although he still managed to escape.

In their next confrontation, Komodo used Naomi as bait, leading Green Arrow to the Queen family mausoleum. This time, Ollie emerged the victor, stabbing Komodo's left eye out with an arrow.

The Outsiders War

When Golgotha, leader of the Spear Clan, brought the clans of the Outsiders together, Komodo, believing Golgotha to be an inferior leader, killed him and took over leadership of the Outsiders for himself. The clans that pledged their loyalty to Komodo began a plan to take over Europe, but were stopped by the intervention of Oliver and Robert Queen, Shado, Magus, and the Sword and Axe Clans, led respectively by Katana and John Butcher. Upon learning that her parents were alive, Emiko turned against Komodo. He then attempted to kill her in retaliation, but she was saved by Robert, at the expense of his own life. After being injured in a fight with Green Arrow, Komodo was killed by Emiko with a single arrow through his chest.

Powers and Abilities

Komodo possessed no superhuman powers, but was a very proficient archer. He was shown to be able to draw a bow faster than Green Arrow, and virtually never missed a shot. The loss of his eye did not seem to seriously hinder his abilities. Komodo is extremely agile and is able to think on his feet.

Equipment and Weapons

Bow and Arrow

A standard bow and arrow combination.

In Other Media

Television

Arrow

Simon Lacroix/Komodo appears in "Sara", the second episode of Arrow's third season. He wears a mask and costume similar to the original version, but is given a different background: he is an assassin-for-hire from the town of Sainte-Sophie, Quebec. He is the prime suspect in the murder of Sara Lance, who had been killed by an archer in the previous episode, but he is discovered to not be her killer.

Although the original version of the character was white, Komodo is portrayed by Matt Ward, a black actor.

deck: Dr. Daman Veteri is a Nobel Prize winning Molecular Engineer who passed up job offers from Oscorp and Horizon Labs in order to work in Dr. Bruce Banner's team of S.H.I.E.L.D. scientists.
description:
Creation

Daman Veteri was created by writer Mark Waid and artist Leinil Yu. He first appeared in Indestructible Hulk #3 (Mar. 2013).

Major Story Arcs

Hulk: Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D

For more information see: Indestructible Hulk: Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D.

Daman is called by Agent Maria Hill, to come to SHIELD headquarters for a job interview. Maria wants Daman to work with Bruce Banner, but first she test him by showing him some pictures of Banner's alter ego the Hulk. Daman doesn't seem shaken by them and wants to work with Banner to "change the world".

Daman gets the job along with three others to work as Banner's personal lab assistants. Later while in Banner's private lab Daman meets his idol, and shows his intelligence when answering Banner's question about what the mystery element is.

issue_credits.name: The Ω Hulk Chapter Twelve; Welcome Home

name: Daman Veteri

deck: A member of Bruce Banner's team of S.H.I.E.L.D. scientists who specializes in Renewable Energies.
description:
Origin

Randall had a very drunk and abusive father, but none the less grew up to be a M.SC. in Renewable Energies.

Creation

Randall Jessup was created by writer Mark Waid and artist Leinil Yu. He first appeared in Indestructible Hulk #3 (Mar. 2013).

Major Story Arcs

Hulk: Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D.

Randall is approached by Maria Hill to join three others as Bruce Banner's personal lab assistants. Randall accepts, claiming due to his past, he believes he can handle Banner if he turns into the Hulk.

Journey into Science

Randall is with Bruce Banner, Iron Man, Maria Hill and Patricia Wolman when they find Zadian's hidden island in the Pacific Ocean. Randall stays with the SHIELD team on the boat when Tony and Bruce head into the island.

issue_credits.name: The Ω Hulk Chapter Twelve; Welcome Home

name: Randall Jessup

deck: An Australian scientist and a former criminal whose record was cleared by S.H.I.E.L.D. so she can work in Bruce Banner's team of scientists.
description:
Origin

Melinda Leucenstern is a Psy.D., M.S., who is well versed in any number of psychological calming techniques. She has a tendency to work for the wrong side of the law but her latest stint in the Australia penal system has forced her to change her views on who she should work for.

Creation

Melinda Leucenstern was created by writer Mark Waid and artist Leinil Yu. She first appeared in Indestructible Hulk #3 (Mar. 2013).

Major Story Arcs

Hulk: Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D.

For more information see: Indestructible Hulk: Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D.

While incarcerated in Perth, Australlia, Melinda is approached by Maria Hill. Maria informs her she has been selected to work with Dr. Banner and S.H.I.E.L.D. Melinda informs Maria, that even though she is incarcerated she has been approached by HYDRA and Egghead, but she'd rather work with Banner.

Melinda is present when the team meets with Banner for the first time. Like the others she is calm when Banner tests them, by pretending to Hulk-out. Melinda also steps up when Banner asks the team what they could do with a chip of Uru, but before she can give him her ideas, Banner is called away.

Gods and Monsters

Blind Rage

Agent of T.I.M.E.
name: Melinda Leucenstern

deck: A Microneural Biologist and a huge fan of Bruce Banner suffering from Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease. She is part of Banner's team of S.H.I.E.L.D. scientists.
description:
Creation

Patricia Wolman was created by writer Mark Waid and artist Leinil Yu. She first appeared in Indestructible Hulk #3 (Mar. 2013).

Major Story Arcs

Hulk: Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D

For more information see: Indestructible Hulk: Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D.

Maria Hill flies to Carson City, Nevada, to meet with Patricia, and offer her a job working with three others as Bruce Banner's lab assistants. Patricia jumps at the opportunity, claiming the pay is worth the risk. Later Patricia is there in the lab when Banner first meets his team, but she is very quiet, choosing to sit back and watch as the other assistants try to impress Banner with their knowledge of Uru Metal.
name: Vista

deck: An immortal shapeshifter, and representative of the mask within the Outsiders.
description:
Creation

Magus was created by Green Arrow writer Jeff Lemire and artist Andrea Sorrentino.

Origin

An enigmatic character that seems claims to be an immortal. Not much is know about him. It is still uncertain whether Magus is his name or a title. At first he told Green Arrow that the 7th clan of the Outsiders was long lost forgotten, but he was later revealed to be the leader(or possibly only member) of the mask clan.

Major Story Arcs

The Kill Machine

The Magus sporadically appears to aid and direct Oliver. He later reveals to Ollie his fathers past and his connection to the mysterious Outsiders.

The Outsiders War

Butcher and the Magus appear to be consolidating all the rogue clans in preparation for war with the Outsiders.

Powers and Abilities

Immortal - Claims to be an immortal and survived lethal attacks disguised as Green Arrow, faking his death

Shape Shifting - Recently demonstrated the ability to change his shape and clothes.

Teleport - Appears and disappears on a whim.

Unarmed Combat - Displays enough proficiency for unarmed combat.

Gas Creation - During the Outsiders War he created a smoke that seemed to confuse or knock out enemies

deck: A young Gotham street thug, who was rescued from Knightfall by Batgirl, and later develops a crush on her.
description:
Origin

Ricky was a young street thug who went by the name "Killa Anon." After running afoul of Knightfall and her Disgraced, he was able to be saved by Batgirl who he developed a bit of an infatuation with.

He has since begun turning his life around, and is later seen helping out at a soup kitchen.

Creation

Ricky was created by Gail Simone and Alitha Martinez. He first appeared in 2012's Batgirl #10.

Major Story Arcs

Knightfall Descends

Ricky and Batgirl first met when he and some fellow thugs were performing multiple carjackings in a parking structure where a high-class charity auction was taking place nearby. Batgirl was giving them all a thorough beating until Ricky tried to make a getaway, only to run afoul of a bear-trap of all things. His leg badly caught in the trap, Batgirl tried her best to keep him calm and talking while she called the paramedics. Some people who claimed to be part of the security detail for the event then came and convinced Batgirl to leave Ricky in their care.

These people were actually part of Knightfall's Disgraced however, and Ricky was later seen by Batgirl being precariously held over a ledge by Bonebreaker, after they'd amputated his injured leg. Bonebreaker then let Ricky fall to his death as a test for Batgirl, which she failed in their opinion by saving Ricky from his fall. While Batgirl fought the Disgraced, Ricky seemed to get away to safety, but the Disgraced unfortunately managed to track him down again.

When Batgirl came to confront Knightfall at her headquarters, the Disgraced taunted her by telling her they'd already killed Ricky after an extensive bit of torture. Batgirl later found him alive in a cage however, albeit in much worse condition than before. Ricky was immensely grateful to Batgirl for having come for him. Knightfall then stepped in suddenly though and stabbed Batgirl in the back before Ricky could warn her.

Despite the wound, Batgirl fought valiantly against Knightfall, and Ricky was even able to help her when he reached out of the cage and held Knightfall still for Batgirl to hit her. Batgirl thanked Ricky and called him a hero for his help. With Knightfall finally beaten, Ricky and Batgirl supported each other as they left to get patched up.

Origin

A reincarnation of The Buddha.

Character Development

Charlie Llama is a mentor to the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, as well as being a teacher to Master Splinter. His nemesis is Mang Thrasha, an evil sorcerer. After sacrificing his own life to protect others, Charlie was reincarnated in the body of Jang La's son.

Powers and Abilities

Charlie's only power is the persuasive force of peace and love.

deck: A character from TMNT.
description:
Origin

Mistia is a very powerful sorceress.

Character Development

Mistia lives in the trash-filled underworld far below the sewers. The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and April O'Neil find her lair while looking for a place to meditate.

Powers and Abilities

Mistia's most notable power is the ability to affect matter, which she uses to turn the trash around her into deadly weapons, gadgets and robots.

deck: Sky-Pirate is the Captain of the Flying Dutchman. He was hired by Phillip Marksbury to kill Batwing.
description:
Creation

Sky-Pirate was created by Fabian Nicieza and Fabrizio Fiorentino for Batwing #17.

Major Story Arcs

Batwing

After Batwing sent Ancil Marksbury to jail for killing numerous young women, Ancil's father, Phillip Marksbury, hired Sky-Pirate to kill Batwing. While Batwing was patrolling, Sky-Pirate shot him from the sky with some heavy explosives taking away Batwing's wings.
name: Sky-Pirate

deck: When Batwing made sure that Phillip Marksbury's son was arrested, Marksbury became a very powerful enemy and was determined to kill Batwing as revenge.
description:
Creation

Phillip Marksbury was created by Allan Jefferson and Fabian Nicieza during their run on Batwing.

Major Story Arcs

Batwing

After Batwing sent Phillip's son, Ancil Marksbury, to prison, Phillip swore that he would get revenge on Batwing. He hired Sky-Pirate to kill Batwing and Dawn to break Ancil out of the holding cells where he was being kept.
name: Phillip Marksbury

When his master launched his stellar genocide, the Avengers broke into the Ark and Qu'lar was one of the few aliens with the ability of talking. He wants to prevent the Avengers from getting into his Master's inner sanctum.

Unfortunately, he is hit by one of Captain Marvel's beam and defeated.

Xiambor is a monster.

In the very first quest for the Six Soul Gems, Thanos slew Xiambor in order to take the gem from him. At the time the Mad Titan had not discovered that each gem had a certain power of its own.

deck: Reece Talbot is a nurse and the legal caretaker of Declan Thomas, who she has been taking care of as a live-in patient for the past 5 years. Declan does not communicate or do anything - everybody thinks he is crazy. To Reece he is a mystery and she needs to solve it.
description:
Origin

Reece Talbot is a twenty-nine years of age and a beautiful young woman who lives in Boston, Massachusetts. She is a nurse and the legal caretaker of Declan Thomas, who lives at her apartment as a live-in patient. Five years ago, she got Declan released into here custody from a mental institute that couldn't help him anymore.

Creation

Reece Talbot was created by Paul Tobin and Juan Ferreyra, and first appeared in Colder #1; published by Dark Horse Comics in 2012.

Character Evolution

Reece is not much of a social person though she got the looks and it seems every men tries to get on a date with her. However, Reece prefers to stay at home and look after Declan Thomas, her live-in patient who is different and unlike anybody else. He does not communicate or do much at all. Besides, his body temperature is so low and cold, he shouldn't even live anymore. To Reece Declan is a mystery and she wants to solve it. Instead of going out on dates, she spends most of the time talking and reading to Declan without any response.  
 
One day, when she least expected it, Declan calls her name "Reece? I think, it's time we had a talk!"
name: Reece Talbot

deck: Ally of Phazer.

deck: Jake Niman was an Afghanistan war vet who was caught in a crossfire that injured him and killed his family.  A Super Soldier Serum variant was used to transform him into Johnny Nightmare.
description:
Origin

Jake Niman was a special forces soldier who was involved in an attempt at developing another Super Soldier Serum. When he returned home to his wife and daughter they were all caught in crossfire. Jake survived. The Punisher came to visit Jake in the hospital and eventually helped him track down and kill the men who killed his family. During their investigation Jake and the Punisher discovered the the attack on Jake's family was intentional. The goal was to kill Jake because he had committed atrocities in Afghanistan after being given the Super Soldier Serum. This revelation apparently causes Jake Niman to become Johnny Nightmare - a name he had adopted when he was performing missions in Afghanistan. Believing everyone to be his enemy he attacked the Punisher and went on a rampage through New York City until Punisher stopped him.

Creation

Johnny Nightmare debuted in Punisher: Nightmare #1 written by Scott M. Gimple with art by Mark Texeira. He was the focus of the five-issue limited series Punisher: Nightmare in which his origin is told through flashbacks and a running adventure with Punisher.
name: Johnny Nightmare

deck: A Vietcong Captain during the Vietnam War whom encountered Nick Fury on different occasions
description:
Brief History

Letrong was a Vietcong soldier that had infiltrated the French forces in then-time French Indo-China. He met up with Nick Fury and George Hatherly and acted like he was a soldier whom wanted to help the French and Americans. However, after a brutal assault on his base by the Vietcong, Letrong revealed himself to Nick Fury as Captain Giap of the Vietcong. He and his forces had killed all the Americans and French soldiers except Nick Fury, whom they released to send a message to the outside world.

Years later, Nick Fury was told by the CIA that Giap was a prominent captain of the Vietcong and his teaching-skills had been of valuable asset to them. Therefore, he should be killed. Nick Fury and Frank Castle (before he became the Punisher) where tasked with killing him but where captured themselves. Here Giap reveals that it was his plan to let the Americans know where he was so he could capture them, and at the same time use the media to win the war. He tells them that Fury and Castle where not send there to kill him because of his teaching skills for the Vietcong, but because he had information about top US diplomats being involved in drug-trafficking.

Fury and Frank Castle however manage to escape and try to get rid of all the evidence against the U.S. While Fury is tasked with this, Frank Castle tries to draw the attention of the Vietcong by shooting at the. Eventually Captain Letrong Giap finds Fury in one of his offices and hold him at gunpoint, asking him why he wanted to cover for the U.S. in their drug trafficking. He also told Nick that he knew he was going to hell for what he had done to people, but that he did not care because he loved his country so much. But before Nick can answer him, Captain Giap was shot in the neck by a sniper-bullet, courtesy of Frank Castle, several miles away. Nick and Frank soon afterwards made their escape, with their target dead. They just barely made it out after Captain Giap's camp was bombed by U.S. forces. Although dead, Captain Giap had shaken Nick's believes in his government. Many years later, Letrong Giap turned out to be alive and well. He, now an elderly man, met Nick Fury in America at a war-memorial. Giap told Nick that he had lived in America for the remainder of his years.
